| nationalteam-update = 29 June 2009 (UTC) }} '''Mark James Noble''' (born 8 May 1987) is an English [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[central midfielder]] and is captain of [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]. He has played almost all his youth and first team football for West Ham apart from two short loan spells, at [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] and [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]]. He has played for [[England national football team|England]] at [[England national under-16 football team|U16]], [[England national under-17 football team|U17]], [[England national under-18 football team|U18]], [[England national under-19 football team|U19]] and [[England national under-21 football team|U21]] levels. He captained the U21 side, scoring three goals in 20 appearances. Noble is the longest serving player in West Ham's current squad, having been in the first team since 2004. He is West Ham's first-choice taker for penalty kicks and has won the club's Hammer of the Year trophy twice.
In 2014, he was ranked in the top five penalty takers in the top European leagues and was in the top 10 in the world based on the percentage of penalties successfully converted since 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/england-should-pray-penalties-world-3209514 |title=Why England should PRAY for penalties at the World Cup — and why we should take Mark Noble — Mirror Online |author=Richard Beech |work=mirror |accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref> Noble has played more [[Premier League]] games for West Ham than any other player.
==Club career==
===Early career=== Born in [[Canning Town]], East London, Noble played for Barking Colts and moved to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]'s academy at age 11. His father, however, who would drive him to training, could not always arrange the time to get Noble to training sessions due to the distance from their home in [[Beckton]]. Local side [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] showed an interest and Noble signed as a youth player.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tribalfootball.com/articles/west-ham-hero-noble-why-i-left-arsenal-3998604#.Uw45a8LxuM8 |title=West Ham hero Noble: Why I left Arsenal |publisher=Tribal Football |date=26 December 2013 |accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref> He became the youngest player ever to appear in their reserve team, aged 15.<ref name=whufc>{{cite web |title=Mark Noble Profile |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/mark-noble-west-ham_2228487_29719 |publisher=www.whufc.com |accessdate=11 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120817113941/http://www.whufc.com/articles/mark-noble-west-ham_2228487_29719 |archivedate=17 August 2012}}</ref> He became a trainee in July 2003<ref name="sbase2">{{cite web |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/players_details.sd?playerid=37804 |title=Soccerbase: Mark Noble |publisher= |accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref> and made his debut in the senior team at the age of just 17 in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] in August 2004 in a 2–0 win against [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]].<ref name="sbase2"/> He made his league debut in the [[Football League Championship|Championship]] in January 2005, in a 4–2 defeat away at [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].<ref name="sbase2"/> On 30 May 2005, Noble played in the [[2005 Football League Championship play-off Final]] which saw West Ham beat [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]] 1–0 to secure a return to the [[Premier League]]. He had entered the game as an 82nd-minute substitute for [[Shaun Newton]].<ref name="2005pof">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/4573799.stm |title=West Ham 1–0 Preston |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref>{{cquote|We think very highly of Mark. If he keeps on working hard and continues to develop as he has, there is no reason why he can't become a top player for this club.<ref name=Pathe>{{cite web |title=BRAVO WEST HAM (aka WEST HAM BEAT MUNICH AND WIN EUROPEAN CUP) video newsreel film |url=http://backup.britishpathe.com/record.php?id=40881 |publisher=Britishpathe.com |accessdate=9 February 2012}}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> |||[[Alan Pardew]], 2005}} [[File:2005 Championship play-off bus.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Open top bus for winners of [[2005 Football League Championship play-off Final]]. Noble with trophy and flag]] Noble won the Young Hammer of the Year<ref>{{cite news |title=Mark's Big Finish |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/marks-big-finish-20050505_2236884_1138332 |publisher=whufc.com |date=5 May 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120921085607/http://www.whufc.com/articles/marks-big-finish-20050505_2236884_1138332 |archivedate=21 September 2012}}</ref> and the runner-up to the [[West Ham United F.C.#Hammer Of The Year|Hammer of the Year]] awards despite making his debut only four months previously.<ref name=whufc />
Upon West Ham's return to the Premier League, he featured in only five League games in the [[2005–06 West Ham United F.C. season|2005–06 season]], including those against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] on 20 November 2005 and against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on 27 November, but after a game against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on 10 December, he found regular playing time harder to come by and was sent out on loan. He did not play for West Ham at all in 2006.<ref name="sbase2"/><ref name="whustats">{{cite web |url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=802&united=Mark_Noble |title=Welcome to the Wonderful World of West Ham United Statistics — Mark Noble |publisher=www.westhamstats.info |accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref>
====Loan periods==== Noble was subsequently loaned to [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/hull_city/4674790.stm |title=Noble joins Hull for three months |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 February 2006 |accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref> where he made five appearances.<ref name=sbase2 /> His Hull debut came on 18 February 2006 in a 1–0 away defeat by [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/4703636.stm |title=Cardiff 1–0 Hull |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 February 2006 |accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref> Noble's loan ended early after he suffered an injury to his lower back.<ref name=indie>[http://sport.independent.co.uk/football/comment/article2491790.ece ''"Mark Noble: Claret and blue, through and through"''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930171242/http://sport.independent.co.uk/football/comment/article2491790.ece |date=30 September 2007 }}, ''The Independent on Sunday'', 17 June 2007. Retrieved 17 June 2007.</ref>
Noble signed a three-month loan with [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] in August 2006<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/i/ipswich_town/4786277.stm |title=''"Noble and Walton sign for Ipswich"'' |publisher= |accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref> in the hope of gaining necessary first-team experience. He played 13 games in the Championship and scored his first professional goal on 12 September in a 2–1 home win over [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/5330028.stm |title=Ipswich 2–1 Coventry |publisher=BBC |date=12 September 2006 |accessdate=4 February 2010}}</ref>
===Return to West Ham=== Noble scored his first goal for West Ham against [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]], the side's first of three in a 3–0 home win in January 2007 in the third round of the [[FA Cup]], from an assist by [[Carlos Tevez]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/6214031.stm |title=West Ham 3–0 Brighton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 January 2007 |accessdate=27 February 2014 |author=Lyon, Sam}}</ref> On 4 March, he scored his first Premiership goal and the opening goal of the game, against Tottenham at [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]] in a game West Ham eventually lost 4–3 in the final seconds.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/6392467.stm |title=West Ham 3–4 Tottenham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 March 2007 |accessdate=27 February 2014 |author=Fletcher, Paul}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=West Ham United v Tottenham Hotspur, 04 March 2007 |url=http://www.11v11.com/matches/west-ham-united-v-tottenham-hotspur-04-march-2007-277158/ |publisher=www.11v11.com |accessdate=22 January 2013}}</ref> He played 11 games in all competitions, scoring three goals in the [[2006–07 West Ham United F.C. season|2006–07 season]].<ref name=whustats/>
====2007–08 season==== Noble established his place in [[Alan Curbishley]]'s side during the [[2007–08 West Ham United F.C. season|2007–08 season]], starting nearly all games when fit. He scored his first penalty for the club on 18 August 2007 in a 1–0 away win against [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] after [[Colin Doyle (footballer)|Colin Doyle]] had fouled [[Craig Bellamy]].<ref name=whustats/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/6941856.stm |title=Birmingham 0–1 West Ham United |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 August 2007 |accessdate=27 February 2014 |author=Sanghera, Mandeep}}</ref> He was out for several weeks in November 2007 after he had played through an injury for the last several months without letting the medical staff know.<ref>{{cite news |title="Naive" Noble out for two weeks |url=http://www.guardian-series.co.uk/archive/2007/11/09/West+Ham+%28westham%29/1822042._Naive__Noble_out_for_two_weeks/ |publisher=[[Waltham Forest Guardian]] |date=9 November 2007}}</ref> In January 2008, Noble scored the only goal in a 1–0 victory over Liverpool from the penalty spot, after Liverpool defender [[Jamie Carragher]] had brought down [[Freddie Ljungberg]] in the last few seconds of second-half added time. His performance in the match was described as "exceptional".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/7210594.stm |title=West Ham United 1–0 Liverpool |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 January 2008 |accessdate=27 February 2014 |author=Chowdhury, Saj}}</ref>
====2008–09 season==== The [[2008–09 West Ham United F.C. season|2008–09 season]] did not start well for Noble, as he was sent off for two bookable offences in a 3–0 loss away at [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], the first away game of the season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Report: Manchester City vs West Ham United |url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=246349&cc=5901&league=ENG.1 |publisher=[[ESPN|espn.com]] |date=24 August 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604124920/http://soccernet.espn.go.com/report?id=246349 |archivedate=4 June 2011}}</ref> After serving his suspension he came back to score an equaliser against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] after West Ham went a goal down with West Brom coming back to win 3–2. This was one of five goals he scored in the season with three coming from the penalty spot.<ref name=whustats/> After Alan Curbishley left in September, he remained in the first team under new manager [[Gianfranco Zola]]. He celebrated his 100th appearance for the Hammers by scoring against Blackburn at [[Ewood Park]] on 21 March 2009 to secure a 1–1 draw.<ref>[http://www.whufc.com/page/News/0,,12562~1598273,00.html Ton-up Noble earns draw] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090322232131/http://www.whufc.com/page/News/0%2C%2C12562~1598273%2C00.html |date=22 March 2009 }} www.whufc.com</ref> In April, he signed a contract extension tying him to the club until 2013.<ref>{{cite news |title=Duo hammer out new deals |url=http://www.premierleague.com/page/Headlines/0,,12306~1616190,00.html |publisher=PremierLeague.com |date=7 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090411060622/http://www.premierleague.com/page/Headlines/0%2C%2C12306~1616190%2C00.html |archivedate=11 April 2009 |df=}}</ref>
====2009–10 season==== Noble began the [[2009–10 West Ham United F.C. season|2009–10 season]] well, scoring West Ham's first goal of the new season, in a 2–0 win over Premier League newcomers Wolves.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/aug/15/premier-league-wolves-west-ham-united |title=Premier League: Wolves 0–2 West Ham United |author=Mikey Stafford |work=the Guardian |accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref> Under Gianfranco Zola, Noble established himself in central midfield in a diamond that included [[Scott Parker (footballer)|Scott Parker]] as his partner and [[Jack Collison]] and [[Valon Behrami]] on the wings.<ref>[http://www.ilfordrecorder.co.uk/content/west_ham_united_football_club/story.aspx?brand=REConline&category=hammers&tBrand=RECONLINE&tCategory=HAMMERSNEW&itemid=WeED28%20Oct%202009%2016%3A31%3A15%3A183 Jack's a part of the precious diamond]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He would only score one other goal during the season – a penalty after [[Habib Beye]] had fouled [[Zavon Hines]] – in a 2–1 home win against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on 4 November 2009.<ref name=whustats/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8334228.stm |title=West Ham 2–1 Aston Villa |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 November 2009 |accessdate=27 February 2014 |author=Roopanarine, Les}}</ref>
====2010–11 season==== With West Ham now managed by [[Avram Grant]], Noble continued to be a regular member of the first team. He played 26 of a possible 38 games in the Premier League missing a month of the season after an [[appendectomy]] as West Ham were relegated after finishing in 20th and bottom place.<ref name=whustats/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-c832675194b64f0c8329bba43a451023.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924043658/http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-c832675194b64f0c8329bba43a451023.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 September 2015 |title=West Ham midfielder Noble out after appendectomy |agency=Associated Press |date=2 November 2010 |accessdate=28 February 2014}}</ref> He scored four league goals, all were penalties including two in one game. On 2 April 2011 against Manchester United his two penalties had put West Ham 2–0 up only for [[Wayne Rooney]] to score a hat-trick which, with another goal by [[Javier Hernández]], won the game 4–2 for Manchester United.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9439820.stm |title=West Ham 2–4 Manchester United |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 April 2011 |accessdate=28 February 2014 |author=Sanghera, Mandeep}}</ref>
====2011–12 season==== [[File:NolanTomkinsNoble - Wembley 2012.jpg|thumb|230px|right|Noble (front) after the [[2012 Football League Championship play-off Final]]]]
During the [[2011–12 West Ham United F.C. season|2011–12 season]] with West Ham now back in the Championship, Noble scored eight goals, seven of which were penalties,<ref name=whustats/> his only goal from open play coming in a 4–0 away win against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20120406/barnsley-0-4-west-ham-united-ft_2236884_2725820 |title=Barnsley 0–4 West Ham United |publisher=www.whufc.com |accessdate=27 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160115192624/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20120406/barnsley-0-4-west-ham-united-ft_2236884_2725820 |archivedate=15 January 2016 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> Having twice previously been runner-up, Noble was named [[West Ham United F.C.#Hammer of the Year|Hammer of the Year]] for the [[2011–12 West Ham United F.C. season|2011–12 season]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Noble voted Hammer of the Year |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20120430/noble-voted-hammer-of-the-year_2236884_2754663 |publisher=whufc.com |accessdate=1 May 2012 |date=30 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502025659/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20120430/noble-voted-hammer-of-the-year_2236884_2754663 |archivedate=2 May 2012 |df=}}</ref> In May 2012 Noble played in the [[2012 Football League Championship play-off Final]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] against [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] which West Ham won 2–1 to return to the Premier League after a one-year absence.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/18044378 |title=Blackpool 1–2 West Ham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 May 2012 |accessdate=27 February 2014 |author=Fletcher, Paul}}</ref> By the end of the season, he had played 49 games in all competitions, missing just one of their Championship games.<ref name=whustats/>
====2012–13 season==== [[File:Mark Noble free kick.jpg|thumb|left|210px|Mark Noble takes a free kick during the 2012–13 season]]
In September 2012, Noble signed a new three-year contract with an option for a further two years.<ref>{{cite news |title=MARK NOBLE SIGNS NEW WEST HAM DEAL |url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/football/view/273837/Mark-Noble-signs-new-West-Ham-deal/ |accessdate=25 September 2012 |newspaper=www.dailstar.co.uk |date=25 September 2012}}</ref> In February 2013, he was out injured after having been diagnosed with a compression of the [[thoracic outlet]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20131118/hammers-publish-important-research_2236884_3536759 |title=Hammers publish important research |publisher=www.whufc.com |date=18 November 2013 |accessdate=27 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208001248/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20131118/hammers-publish-important-research_2236884_3536759 |archivedate=8 December 2013 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> He did not return until 17 April 2013 in a 2–2 home draw against Manchester United.<ref name=whustats/> The missing games saw Noble's tally for the season at 31 games in all competitions with four goals scored. Three goals were penalties with his one-goal from open play coming in a 4–1 home win against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 20 October 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/19939627 |title=West Ham 4–1 Southampton |date=20 October 2012 |accessdate=27 February 2014 |author=Hassan, Nabil}}</ref>
====2013–14 season==== Noble scored three goals in the [[2013–14 West Ham United F.C. season|2013–14 season]], the only one from open play being the second goal in a 2–0 away win over Cardiff City in January, despite the team being down to ten men after a [[James Tomkins (footballer)|James Tomkins]] sending off.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20140111/cardiff-city-0-west-ham-2_2234233_70940 |title=11 January 2014, Cardiff City 0 – 2 West Ham — Match Report — Match — West Ham United |publisher= |accessdate=12 September 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140912135218/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20140111/cardiff-city-0-west-ham-2_2234233_70940 |archivedate=12 September 2014 |df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 6 May 2014, Noble received his second [[West Ham United F.C.#Hammer of the Year|Hammer of the Year]], beating runner up [[Adrián (footballer)|Adrián]] and third-placed James Tomkins. On the same awards night, Noble also won the Players' Player of the Year accolade.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/articles/20140506/201314-player-awards-live_2236884_3809162|archive-url=https://archive.today/20140506221620/http://www.whufc.com/articles/20140506/201314-player-awards-live_2236884_3809162|dead-url=yes|archive-date=6 May 2014 |title=2013/14 Player Awards, |date=5 May 2014}}</ref>
====2014–15 season==== Noble missed a penalty in a 0–1 home defeat by Tottenham on 16 August 2014, the opening game of the [[2014–15 Premier League|season]], but scored his first goal of the season in the next home game, on 30 August, a 1–3 home defeat by Southampton.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28906779 |title=West Ham 1–3 Southampton |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref> On 29 November 2014, Noble became West Ham's record appearance maker in the Premier League with his appearance against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] being his 205th Premier League game, overtaking [[Steve Potts (footballer)|Steve Potts]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eplindex.com/61936/noble-sets-premier-league-record-west-ham.html |title=Noble sets Premier League Record for West Ham |publisher=EPL Index.com |date=30 November 2014 |accessdate=30 November 2014 |author=Burke, Liam}}</ref> Noble signed a contract extension which would keep him at West Ham until 2020, with an option for a further year, on 26 February 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31637830 |title=Mark Noble signs West Ham contract extension to 2020 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=26 February 2015}}</ref>
====2015–16 season and testimonial==== Noble's first goal of the season came from the penalty spot in a 3–4 home defeat by Premier League newcomers, [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] on 22 August 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33944756 |title=West Ham 3–4 Bournemouth |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=22 December 2015}}</ref> The following week, he scored the second goal in a 3–0 away win against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]; this was West Ham's first win at [[Anfield]] since 1963.<ref name="away at anfield">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34025305 |title=Liverpool 0–3 West Ham United |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=22 December 2015}}</ref> Noble made his 350th senior appearance for West Ham on 6 February 2016, in a 1–0 defeat away at Southampton.<ref name="350a">{{cite news |url=http://www.newhamrecorder.co.uk/sport/football/west-ham/west_ham_skipper_fumes_at_missed_opportunity_at_southampton_1_4409851 |title=West Ham skipper fumes at missed opportunity at Southampton |work=Newham Recorder |date=8 February 2016 |accessdate=1 March 2016}}</ref> The following week, he scored his third goal of the season, netting West Ham's equalizer in the 77th minute of their 2–2 draw away at [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]]. On 22 December 2015, it had been announced that Noble was to be granted a [[Testimonial match|testimonial]] by West Ham following his long service to the club. The game was played on 28 March 2016 between a West Ham XI and a West Ham United all-stars team made up of former players, with all proceeds going to charity.<ref name="SkyTestimonial">{{citenews|title=West Ham captain Mark Noble scores in testimonial match|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/10221130/west-ham-captain-mark-noble-scores-in-testimonial-match|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|date=29 March 2016|first=Nick|last=Lustig}}</ref><ref>{{citenews|title=West Ham’s Mark Noble: I didn’t want a testimonial and Upton Park to be half-empty|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/27/west-ham-united-mark-noble-testimonial-upton-park|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=27 March 2016|first=Jacob|last=Steinberg}}</ref> The game was won 6–5 by the West Ham XI in front of 36,000 spectators and featured a goal by [[Paolo Di Canio]] and two by [[Dean Ashton]], including a [[bicycle kick]] described as "stunning".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2016/March/28-March/Noble-It-couldn-t-have-gone-any-better |title=Noble — It couldn't have gone any better — West Ham United |publisher= |accessdate=29 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160331051333/http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2016/March/28-March/Noble-It-couldn-t-have-gone-any-better |archivedate=31 March 2016 |df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On 10 May 2016, Noble became the final man to lead a West Ham United team out at [[Boleyn Ground|Upton Park]], as the Hammers went on to win their final game at their former home 3–2 against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11661/10277257/mark-noble-says-west-ham-win-at-boleyn-farewell-was-written-in-the-stars |title=Mark Noble says West Ham win at Boleyn farewell was 'written in the stars' |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=11 May 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== In March 2017 sections of [[West Ham United F.C. supporters|West Ham supporters]] called for him to be dropped from the team. Noble described the season as "the most difficult of his career".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/10801334/west-ham-captain-mark-noble-hits-back-at-critics-calling-for-him-to-be-dropped |title=West Ham captain Mark Noble hits back at critics calling for him to be dropped |publisher= |accessdate=18 May 2017}}</ref> On 8 April 2017, having played against [[Swansea City F.C.|Swansea City]], Noble marked his 400th appearance for West Ham becoming the 19th player to pass this number.<ref>{{citenews|title=Stat's A Fact - Noble: The 400 Club|url=http://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2017/april/09-april/stats-fact-noble-400-club|publisher=[[West Ham United F.C.|whufc.com]]|date=9 April 2017}}</ref> He played 35 games in all competitions for West Ham in the [[2016–17 in English football|2016–17 season]] scoring five goals, two in the [[Europa League]] and three in the Premier League.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.westhamstats.info/westham.php?west=2&ham=802&united=Mark_Noble |title=Mark Noble |website=www.westhamstats.info |accessdate=18 May 2017}}</ref> His season finished early with two games remaining for West Ham as he required an abdominal operation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/10873551/mark-noble-to-miss-last-two-west-ham-fixtures-as-he-requires-abdominal-surgery |title=Mark Noble to miss last two West Ham fixtures as he requires abdominal surgery |publisher= |accessdate=18 May 2017}}</ref>
====2017–18 season==== Noble marked his 300th Premier League appearance with a goal from the penalty spot against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on 16 December 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Stoke 0–3 West Ham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 December 2017 |accessdate=16 December 2017 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42290587}}</ref> In March 2018, there were protests against [[David Sullivan (businessman)|David Sullivan]] and the West Ham United board at the [[London Stadium]] during a 3-0 home defeat to [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]]. There were four pitch invasions with one fan approaching Noble on the pitch.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43358711 |title=Fans approach players during West Ham's defeat by Burnley at London Stadium |date=10 March 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=17 March 2018}}</ref> In scenes described as "horrific", Noble grappled with the supporter, throwing him to the ground.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/west-ham-shame-as-fans-invadepitch-czpvmmgxn |title=West Ham shame as fans invade pitch |first=Paul |last=Rowan |date=11 March 2018 |accessdate=18 March 2018 |newspaper=The Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.joe.co.uk/sport/mark-noble-throws-west-ham-supporter-to-the-ground-during-pitch-invasion-167264 |title=Mark Noble throws West Ham supporter to the ground during pitch invasion - JOE.co.uk |publisher= |accessdate=18 March 2018}}</ref> On 5 May 2018, he scored the second goal in a 2–0 away win at [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], a result which ensured West Ham's survival in the Premier League. Noble described the goal, a [[Volley (football)|volley]] from the edge of the [[penalty area]], as "the best of his career".<ref>[https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/west-ham-captain-mark-noble-hails-leicester-goal-as-the-best-of-his-career-a3832141.html]</ref>
==International career== Noble captained the [[England national under-18 football team|England U18 team]].<ref name=whufc /> He was a member of the [[England national under-19 football team|England U19 team]] that beat [[Serbia national under-19 football team|Serbia and Montenegro U19s]] 3–1 in the [[2005 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|2005 European Championship]] [[2005 UEFA European Under-19 Championship#Semi-finals|semi-finals]], although they subsequently lost the [[2005 UEFA European Under-19 Championship#Final|final]] to [[France national under-19 football team|France]].<ref name=times>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article1942679.ece |title=''"Noble cause"'' |publisher= |accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref>
Noble made his debut for the [[England national under-21 football team|England U-21]] team on 11 June 2007, coming on as substitute in the 82nd minute for [[Tom Huddlestone]] in England's 0–0 draw with the [[Czech Republic national under-21 football team|Czech Republic]] during the [[2007 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]], held in the Netherlands.<ref>[https://archive.today/20071029052657/http://www.thefa.com/Euro2007/EnglandNews/Postings/2007/06/EngU21s_vCzechRepublic.htm ''"England held in Arnhem"''], TheFA.com match report, 11 June 2007. Retrieved 11 June 2007.</ref> He established himself in the starting XI for the remaining matches<ref>{{cite news |title=Graft not craft the art for Noble |url=http://www.uefa.com/competitions/under21/news/kind=1/newsid=838501.html |publisher=[[UEFA|uefa.com]] |date=16 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090619101757/http://www.uefa.com/competitions/under21/news/kind%3D1/newsid%3D838501.html |archivedate=19 June 2009 |df=}}</ref> and scored twice in a dramatic semi-final penalty shootout against the [[Netherlands national under-21 football team|Netherlands]] where England lost 13–12.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6766603.stm |title=BBC SPORT — Football — Internationals — Holland U21 1–1 Eng U21 (aet) |publisher= |accessdate=24 March 2016}}</ref> On 11 September 2007, Noble scored his first international goal for the under-21 team against [[Bulgaria national under-21 football team|Bulgaria]] in a 2–0 victory,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6988587.stm |title=''Bulgaria U21 0–2 England U21 '' |publisher= |accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref> followed by two more against the [[Republic of Ireland national under-21 football team|Republic of Ireland]] on 16 October.<ref>[http://www.sportinglife.com/football/news/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/07/10/16/manual_215010.html&TEAMHD=soccer ''Republic of Ireland U21 0–3 England U21 '']{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, sportinglife.com, 16 October 2007. Retrieved 16 October 2007. {{cbignore|bot=medic}}{{dead link|date=March 2016}}</ref>
Noble captained the U21s at the [[2009 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2009 European Championships]] as regular captain [[Steven Taylor (footballer)|Steven Taylor]] had to withdraw due to injury.<ref>{{cite news |title=Pearce considers Noble for captain's role |url=http://www.guardian-series.co.uk/football/4428475.Pearce_considers_Noble_for_captain_s_role/ |publisher=[[Waltham Forest Guardian]] |date=9 June 2009}}</ref> The Young Lions ended the tournament as runners-up, losing 4–0 to [[Germany national under-21 football team|Germany]], with Noble playing his last match for the U21s.
Noble is also eligible to play for the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] national side through his [[County Cork|Cork]]-born grandparents.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lep.co.uk/twitter/Lonergan-could-play-for-Republic.5346266.jp |title=Lonergan could play for Republic |work=lep.co.uk |accessdate=9 June 2009}}</ref> In August 2014, despite stating on numerous occasions about his ambition of playing for [[England national football team|England]] at senior level,<ref>{{cite news |title=Mark Noble: I will never give up on my England dream |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/mark-noble-i-will-never-give-up-on-my-england-dream-9668659.html |work=Evening Standard |date=14 August 2014}}</ref> it was reported by the ''Irish Independent'' that he could be willing to make himself available for the Irish national team.<ref>{{cite news |title=West Ham's Mark Noble ready to declare for Ireland — reports |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/international-soccer/west-hams-mark-noble-ready-to-declare-for-ireland-reports-30546515.html |work=Irish Independent |date=29 August 2014}}</ref>
==Personal life== In May 2016, Noble was granted freedom of the [[Borough of Newham]] for his services to the borough.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newhamrecorder.co.uk/news/freedom_of_the_borough_honours_presented_to_remarkable_people_1_4543650 |title=Freedom of the Borough honours presented to ‘remarkable people’ |author=Kat Hopps |work=Newham Recorder |accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref>
Noble has been married to childhood sweetheart Carly since 2012.<ref>{{citenews|title=Noble loving it all|url=https://www.whufc.com/news/articles/2012/july/06-july/noble-loving-it-all|publisher=[[West Ham United F.C.|whufc.com]]|date=6 July 2012}}</ref> The couple have a son and a daughter.<ref name="SkyTestimonial"/>
